children.name: to talk about other people’s private lives
gossip
children.definition: to spend time talking without a serious purpose, usually about other people’s private lives or behaviour: bép xép, nhiều chuyện
examples: It’s best not to tell Frank anything. You know how he gossips.

children.name: gossip about
examples: Those two old ladies sit there every day, gossiping about everyone in town.

children.name: talk U
children.definition: talk if you say that peopletalk, you mean that theytalkabout other people’s private lives and behaviour, usually in a disapproving way: bàn tán
examples: We mustn’t be seen together in public again. People are starting to talk.

children.name: talk about sb behind their back
children.definition: to talk about someone when they are not present: nói sau lưng ai đó
examples: ▪ I hate people who talk about you behind your back and then pretend to be nice to you when they meet you.

children.name: tongues are wagging
children.definition: used for saying that many people are talking about someone’s private life in an unkind or disapproving way: buôn chuyện
examples: ▪ Tongues are wagging about Hollywood’s newest couple.
set tongues wagging là chủ đề để người khác buôn chuyện
cause people to start talking about you
▪ Thurmond’s marriage so soon after his wife died set tongues wagging.

children.name: gossip
children.definition: to spend time talking to sb, especially sb you are friendly with, about things that are not particularly serious or important: ngồi lê đôi mách, nói chuyện phiếm
examples: Cocteau’s jazz club was the spot where artists gossiped and drank.

children.name: gossip with
examples: I wasn’t doing anything important - just gossiping with a neighbour.

children.name: chatter
children.definition: to talk continuously for a long time about unimportant things - used especially in literature: nói nhảm, nói xàm
examples: The tiny gray-haired woman chattered continuously as she demonstrated how to make a tortilla.

children.name: chatter with
examples: They poured out of the school chattering with their friends.

children.name: chatter about
examples: Michele sat there chattering about her minor ailments to anyone who would listen.

children.name: chatter away/oncontinuously
examples: I could hear the boys chattering away in the other room.

children.name: natter
children.definition: UK informal if two people natter, they talk continuously for a long time about unimportant things: nói ba hoa
examples: natter with
▪ I can’t stand about nattering all day with you
natter about
▪ Keith and Tom were nattering about cars and not doing a stroke of work.

children.name: pass the time of day
children.definition: to have a short, friendly conversation about unimportant things with sb you know, especially when you meet them by chance: chào hỏi, nói chuyện sơ sơ
examples: I just thought I’d stop by and pass the time of day.

children.name: pass the time of day with
examples: Whenever we met in the street, Mr. Kelly would stop and pass the time of day with me.

children.name: shoot the breeze
children.definition: US informal to have an informal conversation about unimportant things: chém gió, “gió nhẹ”
examples: ▪ The men spent their evenings on the porch, shooting the breeze.

children.name: shoot the breeze with
examples: ▪ Hemingway came into the bar almost every morning to read the papers, shoot the breeze with the regulars, and enjoy bracing double daiquiris.

children.name: talk
children.definition: to say sth to sb, or have a conversation: nói chuyện
examples: ▪ We sat around talking for hours.
▪ two friends talking on the phone
talk about
▪ They talked about their favourite pop stars.
talk to/talk withUS
▪ Danny was talking to a girl he’d just met at the bar.
▪ It’s been nice talking to you.
▪ I left Mario talking with my mother.

children.name: speak
children.definition: totalkto someone.Speakis more formal thantalk: nói
examples: ▪ The brothers haven’t spoken since the funeral.

children.name: speak to
examples: ▪ There’s a man from the Times on the phone who wants to speak to you.
▪ I spoke to a few people at the party who knew him.

children.name: say sth
children.definition: say something  nói gì đó
examples: ▪ Did you say something? Sorry - I wasn’t listening.
▪ No one said anything.
▪ The older woman said something in Spanish.

children.name: say something about
examples: ▪ I can remember him saying something about his mother being ill.

children.name: say something to
examples: ▪ Pradeep could hear her saying something to the nurse.

children.name: chat
children.definition: especially British to talk in a friendly and informal way, especially about things that are not very important: trò chuyện, nói chuyện phiếm
examples: ▪ The girls were sitting on the steps, chatting.

children.name: chat about
examples: ▪ We drank our coffee and chatted about our experiences.

children.name: chat with/to
examples: ▪ Harry chatted to a couple of Australian tourists as we waited for the show to begin.

children.name: have a conversation
children.definition: to talk to someone for a period of time: có một cuộc nói chuyện
examples: ▪ Could we just sit down and have a normal conversation without shouting?

children.name: have a conversation about có một cuộc nói chuyện về
examples: ▪ We were sitting around the kitchen table having a conversation about food and restaurants.

children.name: be in conversation
children.definition: to be having a conversation, especially one that takes all your attention: ở trong cuộc nói chuyện, nói chuyện

children.name: be in conversation with
examples: ▪ When I arrived, Diana was already in animated conversation with Mr Summers.

children.name: be deep in conversationso that you do not notice what is happening around you
examples: ▪ The two men were deep in conversation as they walked up the path.

children.name: make conversation/make small talk
children.definition: to make an effort to have a conversation with sb, just in order to seem friendly or polite: nói chuyện xã giao
examples: ▪ I tried to make small talk, but Darden wasn’t interested.
▪ ‘Why did you tell her that?’ ‘I was just making conversation.’
make polite conversation nói chuyện xã giao lịch sự
▪ Sheila was sitting next to the boss’s wife and felt obliged to make polite conversation.

children.name: visit
children.definition: US informal to talk in a relaxed way to sb you know well: thăm hỏi
examples: ▪ Mom and Aunt Jo were sitting drinking coffee and visiting.

children.name: visit with
examples: ▪ I don’t see him that often, but I like to go and visit with him when I can.

children.name: converse
children.definition: to have a conversation: trò chuyện, nói chuyện
examples: We met once and conversed briefly. That was the extent of our acquaintance.

children.name: converse with
examples: The conference gave me an opportunity to meet and converse with VIPs in relaxed surroundings.

children.name: talk
children.definition: to discuss sth serious or important with sb:
examples: Joe, we need to talk.
Is there somewhere we can talk in private?

children.name: talk about
examples: We’ve been talking about getting married.

children.name: talk to/ withUS
examples: You should talk to a lawyer.
Parents should talk with their children about drug abuse.
Gerry wants to talk to his girlfriend before he makes a decision.
It’s important to talk with your kids about drugs, alcohol, and sex.

children.name: talk sport/politics/business etcC1
examples: ‘Let’s not talk politics now,’ said Hugh impatiently.
Whenever they're together, they talk politics.
RegisterIn written English, people usually say that they are going todiscuss,deal with, oraddressa subject rather thantalk aboutit:
In this essay I willdiscussthe problem of over-population.

children.name: speak
children.definition: to talk to sb about sth serious or official.Speakis a little more formal thantalk. You often use it when saying that you willspeakto sb in order to try to get something done: nói chuyện với

children.name: speak to/ speak withUS
examples: Maybe it’s time for you to speak to a lawyer.
The woman had come all the way from Denver to speak with the President.

children.name: speak to/with sb about
examples: I intend to speak to the manager about the way I have been treated.
Have you spoken with Michael about the scheduling conflict?

children.name: have a talk
children.definition: to talk to someone seriously about something you have planned to discuss, especially about a problem or future plans: thảo luận, bàn luận, nói chuyện
examples: ▪ Don and I had a long talk, and I think we understand each other better now.
have a talk about
▪ I think it’s time we had a talk about your future here in the company.
have a talk with
▪ If this behavior continues, I’m going to have to have a little talk with her
.▪ Someone should have a serious talk with Lucy about the amount of alcohol she drinks.

children.name: have a conversation
children.definition: to talk to someone for a period of time about a serious subject: có cuộc trò chyện
examples: ▪ The two leaders had a brief conversation yesterday.

children.name: have a conversation with
examples: ▪ I’ve had conversations with several employers who say there are not enough qualified people to fill the jobs they have.

children.name: have a conversation about
examples: ▪ We need to have a conversation with our lawyers about the will.

children.name: have a word
children.definition: especially spokento talk to sb quickly, and usually privately, about sth serious:
examples: Could I have a word?
have a word with
I’ll have a word with him and see if he’ll help.
His attitude got so bad his manager was forced to have a word with him.
I’d like (to have) a word with you
I’d like a word with you in private.
have a quick/brief word
I was hoping to have a quick word with you.
have/exchange a few words
Could I have a few words with you?
want a wordspokento want to talk to sb, especially in order to criticize them
want a word with
Wait a minute! I want a word with you!

children.name: have a heart-to-heart
children.definition: talk/a heart-to-heart to have a private conversation in which two people both say honestly and sincerely what they feel about sth personal: có cuộc trao đổi thẳng thắn, chân thành
examples: Don’t go in there right now - I think Dean and Carlo are having a heart-to-heart.

children.name: have a heart-to-heart talk/ a heart-to-heart with
examples: If you think your boss doesn’t like you, have a heart-to-heart talk with her.

children.name: talk shop
children.definition: if two or more people who do the same work talk shop, they have a conversation about their work on a social occasion: nói chuyện làm ăn, bàn công việc
examples: I don’t want to go out to dinner with him and his lawyer friends - all they ever do is talk shop.

children.name: to tell sb what you are feeling
get sth off your chest
children.definition: to tell someone about something that has been worrying you or annoying you for a long time so that you feel better afterwards: giãi bày, nói hết nỗi lòng

children.name: ▪ I feel so much better now that I’ve got that off my chest
examples: .▪ Writing to you is a good way to get things off my chest.

children.name: confide in
children.definition: sb to tell sb about sth very private or secret, especially a personal problem, because you feel that you can trust them: tâm sự
examples: ▪ He was a good listener and Elinor found it easy to confide in him.

children.name: confide in sb about
examples: ▪ He wanted desperately to confide in someone about his feelings of failure.

children.name: confide in sb that
examples: ▪ Harriet confided in me that she and Mark were considering divorce.

children.name: pour out your heart
children.definition: /soul  to tell someone everything about some strong emotions that you are feeling, especially feelings of unhappiness: nói ra hết những gì trong lòng
examples: ▪ Suddenly, Jason burst into tears and poured out his heart, telling his mother all about everything.

children.name: pour out your heart/soul to nói ra hết những gì trong lòng với
examples: ▪ I had no idea Kay was so unhappy until she poured out her soul to me last night.
